Replicate your study

Source: vignettes/v10_replicate_study.Rmd
v10_replicate_study.Rmd

This vignette shows how a simulation can be replicated.

Simulate uncertainty on percentiles

Assume the following model is used. This model is a 2-compartment model without absorption compartment which has been fitted on some data.

model <- model_library$my_model1

It contains a variance-covariance matrix with the uncertainty on all the estimated parameters.

model
## [MAIN]
## CL=THETA_CL*exp(ETA_CL)
## V1=THETA_V1*exp(ETA_V1)
## V2=THETA_V2
## Q=THETA_Q
## S1=V1
## 
## [ODE]
## d/dt(A_CENTRAL)=Q*A_PERIPHERAL/V2 + (-CL/V1 - Q/V1)*A_CENTRAL
## d/dt(A_PERIPHERAL)=-Q*A_PERIPHERAL/V2 + Q*A_CENTRAL/V1
## d/dt(A_OUTPUT)=CL*A_CENTRAL/V1
## F=A_CENTRAL/S1
## 
## [DURATION]
## A_CENTRAL=5
## 
## [ERROR]
## CP=F
## OBS_CP=CP*(EPS_PROP + 1)
## Y=OBS_CP
## 
## 
## THETA's:
##   name index    value   fix
## 1   CL     1  4.76756 FALSE
## 2   V1     2 82.64090 FALSE
## 3   V2     3 19.53960 FALSE
## 4    Q     4  3.81451 FALSE
## OMEGA's:
##   name index index2     value   fix type same
## 1   CL     1      1 0.0222955 FALSE  var   NA
## 2   V1     2      2 0.0182225 FALSE  var   NA
## SIGMA's:
##   name index index2     value   fix type
## 1 PROP     1      1 0.0244587 FALSE  var
## Variance-covariance matrix:
##                THETA_CL     THETA_V1     THETA_V2      THETA_Q   SIGMA_PROP
## THETA_CL    1.35466e-02 -1.09688e-03 -0.034486800 -5.62167e-04  1.49242e-05
## THETA_V1   -1.09688e-03  3.70832e+00  0.339263000 -2.44854e-01 -3.91518e-05
## THETA_V2   -3.44868e-02  3.39263e-01  2.366160000 -1.08175e-01  1.92260e-04
## THETA_Q    -5.62167e-04 -2.44854e-01 -0.108175000  2.23365e-01  4.07924e-05
## SIGMA_PROP  1.49242e-05 -3.91518e-05  0.000192260  4.07924e-05  6.60412e-07
## OMEGA_CL    1.76034e-04  1.10661e-04 -0.000612518 -6.66290e-07  1.43299e-07
## OMEGA_V1    2.60655e-05  1.02673e-03 -0.000965465  1.58447e-04 -7.96979e-07
##                OMEGA_CL     OMEGA_V1
## THETA_CL    1.76034e-04  2.60655e-05
## THETA_V1    1.10661e-04  1.02673e-03
## THETA_V2   -6.12518e-04 -9.65465e-04
## THETA_Q    -6.66290e-07  1.58447e-04
## SIGMA_PROP  1.43299e-07 -7.96979e-07
## OMEGA_CL    2.36926e-05 -5.09976e-06
## OMEGA_V1   -5.09976e-06  2.67587e-05
## 
## Compartments:
## A_CENTRAL (CMT=1)
## A_PERIPHERAL (CMT=2)
## A_OUTPUT (CMT=3)

We are interested to see the uncertainty on the simulated concentration percentiles over time. Let’s mimic the protocol that was implemented in the study.

ds <- Dataset(50)
for (day in 0:6) {
  ds <- ds %>% add(Infusion(time=day*24, amount=1000, compartment=1))
}
ds <- ds %>% add(Observations(times=seq(0, 7*24)))

Let’s now simulate this model with or without parameter uncertainty.
Argument replicates specifies how many times the simulation will be replicated.
Argument outfun is a function that is going to be called after each simulation on the output data frame.

results_with_varcov <- model %>% simulate(dataset=ds, dest="RxODE", replicates=50, outfun=~PI(.x, output="Y"), seed=1)
results_with_varcov %>% head()
## # A tibble: 6 x 4
##   replicate  TIME metric value
##       <int> <dbl> <chr>  <dbl>
## 1         1     0 med     0   
## 2         1     0 low     0   
## 3         1     0 up      0   
## 4         1     1 med     2.37
## 5         1     1 low     1.63
## 6         1     1 up      3.06
results_without_varcov <- model %>% disable("VARCOV") %>% simulate(dataset=ds, dest="RxODE", replicates=50, outfun=~PI(.x, output="Y"), seed=1)

Function vpcPlot allows to quickly visualize such results.

vpcPlot(results_with_varcov)

vpcPlot(results_without_varcov)
